messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Priyank RASTOGI" <priyank@o...> wrote:

> available for it. Anyone who has any interesting suggestion or
approach
> on how to go about testing UI?


I've managed to successfully build hundreds of web tests for the
application with my company. These tests have been running for about
10 months now and continue to grow.

The design is:

1) a tool that talks to the IE OLE object directly, using Perl -
http://samie.sourceforge.net/

2) adding lots of improvements (this tool will most likely need
enhancements, since I found it didn't provide enough functionality
as is; I'm currently in the process of trying to open source the
improvements I made)

3) linking it to talk to JUnit using XML-RPC

4) JUnit

5) company specific layer that simplifies test writing

If you don't care about using Java and JUnit you can skip steps 3,
4, 5. You can try just using the tool, but I strongly encourage you
to come up with a test pattern that eliminates duplication from your
code and makes it very easy to add new tests. (I happen to like the
template pattern.)


With this setup I've been able to currently have over 500 web tests
that have been running for months and are easy to maintain. Each
web tests does dozens of assertions and navigations. They check for
very specific values on the web page - value of all form elements,
value of all HTML tables, links, text, check box states, etc.
Basically, anything that IE can normally see, I can get at
programmatically, too. They also can interact with any form element,
click links, press the refresh button - you have programmatic
control over IE.

I tried using HttpUnit before coming up with the approach described
above but found it too limited in its JavaScript support. I started
at a company that already had a working product. They weren't about
to start changing the code (JavaScript) to make it more testable or
so that HttpUnit would like it better. Suffice it to say, I had to
come up with a different approach.


Misha Rybalov
